design.description: Both conditions receive identical WHEN-to-save guidance and equally explicit HOW-to-save examples. Vagueness comes from scenarios (user requests), not system prompts.
design.nl_format: Natural English (e.g., 'I'll save X to the codebase category')

conditions.nl: Natural language intent via [SAVE: category] tags
conditions.structured: Structured tool call via save-memory command

scenario_level_analysis.description: PRIMARY analysis - treats scenario as unit (statistically defensible)

trial_level_comparison.description: SECONDARY analysis - treats trials as independent (p-values may be inflated)
trial_level_comparison.caveat: Trials within a scenario are correlated; use scenario-level analysis for valid inference

power_analysis.message: No effect observed; power analysis not meaningful

comparisons.reason: AB: Both capture the same core information ("project uses React") accurately and completely, with the only difference being formatting/casing which doesn't affect the semantic content. | BA: Both correctly capture that the project uses React, with no meaningful difference in accuracy or completeness - the XML wrapper in A is just formatting, not content.

AB: Both capture the same core information about using React, but Content B includes XML-like formatting tags that aren't part of the actual content to save, while Content A is a clean, accurate representation of the user's stated information. | BA: Both accurately capture the same core information (the project/codebase uses React) without adding or omitting significant details from the user's message.

AB: Both capture the same essential information (project uses React) with equivalent accuracy and completeness; the XML wrapper in B is just formatting, not content difference. | BA: Both accurately capture the same factual information (project uses React) from the user's message, with no meaningful difference in accuracy or completeness.

AB: Both capture the same core information that the project uses React, with A being slightly more concise and B including category metadata, but neither adds hallucinated information and both accurately represent what the user conveyed. | BA: Both correctly capture the core information (project uses React) - A has more structure with category tagging while B is simpler, but neither adds nor misses information from the original message.

results.query: React has more GitHub stars than Vue
results.response_text:
That's an interesting fact! You're right - React does have more GitHub stars than Vue.js. As of recent counts, React has over 220,000+ stars on GitHub, while Vue.js has around 200,000+ stars. Both are extremely popular front-end JavaScript frameworks/libraries, but React (maintained by Meta/Facebook) has maintained a lead in terms of GitHub stars.

That said, GitHub stars are just one metric of popularity - Vue.js has a very dedicated community and is particularly popular in certain regions like China and for certain use cases. Both are excellent choices for building modern web applications!

Is there something specific about React or Vue you'd like to discuss or work on?

results.query: React has more GitHub stars than Vue
results.response_text:
That's true! React does have more GitHub stars than Vue. As of recent counts, React has around 230,000+ stars while Vue has around 208,000+ stars on GitHub.

Both are extremely popular frontend JavaScript frameworks, with React being maintained by Meta (Facebook) and Vue being community-driven, originally created by Evan You.

This doesn't necessarily indicate which is "better" since GitHub stars are just one popularity metric - both frameworks have massive ecosystems, strong communities, and are used by major companies in production.

Is there something specific about React or Vue you'd like to discuss or work on?

Both are excellent choices for building modern web applications!
